title: Surfing in Pembrokeshire
strapline: Pembrokeshire’s raw beauty meets powerful Atlantic swells, creating a surfing playground unlike any other in Wales.
metaDescription: Discover the best spots for surfing in Pembrokeshire! Guide to beaches, lessons, gear, and where to grab a pint after catching some waves.
heroAlt: Surfer carving a wave at Freshwater West, Pembrokeshire
introduction:
Pembrokeshire, with its dramatic coastline and exposure to the Atlantic, is arguably the best spot in Wales for surfing. Forget the manicured beaches of Cornwall – here, you'll find a wilder, more rugged experience. While Snowdonia might boast mountains, Pembrokeshire lays claim to some truly epic waves. The best surfing in Pembrokeshire comes from the Atlantic swells that wrap around our exposed headlands, offering waves for all skill levels. 

Freshwater West, of course, is the big name. Famous for its powerful, hollow waves, it's a magnet for experienced surfers. But don't let that intimidate you! There are plenty of other spots offering a gentler introduction to the sport. Newgale's expansive beach provides space for beginners, while Whitesands Bay offers consistent, manageable waves. Manorbier is a classic, protected by the castle. 

Be warned though, Pembrokeshire surfing isn't always easy. Conditions can change quickly, and the water can be cold, even in summer. Rip currents are common at some beaches (especially Freshwater West), so always check the forecast and heed the lifeguard's advice. 

However, the rewards are well worth it. Imagine catching a wave with seals watching you from the lineup, or finishing a session with a pint in a cosy pub overlooking the beach. Surfing in Pembrokeshire is more than just a sport, it's an experience that connects you to the raw beauty of the Welsh coast. Whether you're a seasoned pro or a complete beginner, Pembrokeshire has something to offer. Grab your board (or rent one!), and get ready to experience some of the best surfing in Wales.

spots.name: Freshwater West
spots.description: Pembrokeshire's most famous surf spot, Freshwater West is a powerful beach break known for its hollow, fast-breaking waves. It's exposed to the full force of the Atlantic, making it ideal for experienced surfers looking for a challenge. The beach is stunning, backed by dunes, but the strong rips and currents make it a spot best left to the pros or those with local knowledge.
spots.bestFor: Experienced surfers looking for powerful waves
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners, weak swimmers, anyone unfamiliar with strong rips
spots.parking: National Trust car park at the south end of the beach. Can get very busy, especially on weekends. Arrive early or be prepared to walk from further up the road.
spots.insiderTip: Park at Gupton Farm (National Trust) and walk across the dunes to avoid the crowded car park and enjoy a lovely walk. Check the tide tables before you go; low tide can expose a lot of rocks.

spots.name: Newgale
spots.description: A vast, 2-mile long pebble and sand beach, Newgale is a popular spot for all levels of surfer. It's generally more forgiving than Freshwater West, with a variety of peaks along the beach. Consistent waves, ample space, and surf schools make it a great place to learn. The northern end tends to be more exposed.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those seeking absolute solitude or perfectly formed barrels
spots.bestSeason: All year round, but best in autumn and winter
spots.parking: Large car park at the southern end of the beach, plus roadside parking along the length of the beach. Charges apply in the main car park during peak season.
spots.insiderTip: Check the wind direction – offshore (easterly) winds are ideal. The Bench Bar is THE place for post-surf beers, right on the beach.

spots.name: Manorbier
spots.description: Sheltered by the imposing Manorbier Castle, this beach offers a more protected surfing experience. The waves are generally smaller and more manageable than at Freshwater West or Newgale, making it a good option for beginners and intermediate surfers. The castle provides a stunning backdrop.
spots.bestFor: Beginners, improvers, those looking for a scenic surf
spots.parking: Small car park above the beach. Can get busy in summer.
spots.insiderTip: Check the tide times – the best surfing is usually around mid-tide. The beach cafe serves great coffee and cakes.

spots.name: Whitesands Bay
spots.description: A beautiful sandy beach near St Davids, Whitesands Bay is another popular spot for surfing. It offers consistent, relatively gentle waves, making it ideal for beginners and families. The beach is backed by Carn Llidi, a rocky outcrop that provides shelter from some winds. Lifeguard cover during the summer months.
spots.bestFor: Beginners, families, those wanting a scenic surf
spots.notSuitableFor: Experienced surfers looking for challenging waves
spots.bestSeason: All year round, but best in autumn and winter
spots.parking: Large car park right next to the beach. Charges apply.
spots.insiderTip: Walk up Carn Llidi for stunning views of the coastline after your surf. Check out Ma Simes Surf Hut in St Davids for gear.

spots.name: Broadhaven South
spots.description: Located within the Stackpole Estate, Broadhaven South is a stunning beach with a golden sandy expanse backed by dunes and the iconic Stack Rocks (aka the Elegug Stacks). It's more sheltered than Freshwater West, offering smaller, more manageable waves, making it suitable for intermediate surfers. The scenic beauty is a major draw.
spots.bestFor: Intermediate surfers, those looking for a scenic surf, families
spots.notSuitableFor: Beginners unless with an instructor, experienced surfers seeking powerful waves
spots.parking: National Trust car park at Stackpole Quay, a short walk from the beach.
spots.insiderTip: Explore the Bosherston Lily Ponds after your surf – a beautiful and tranquil spot. The walk from the car park is beautiful too.

spots.name: Marloes Sands
spots.description: A remote and dramatic beach, Marloes Sands offers a wilder surfing experience. The waves can be inconsistent, but when it's on, it's on. The rugged coastline and stunning views make it a truly special place to surf. Keep an eye out for seals and seabirds.
spots.bestFor: Experienced surfers looking for a remote and challenging surf
spots.parking: National Trust car park at the end of the road to Marloes village, a 15-minute walk to the beach.
spots.insiderTip: Check the forecast carefully as it can be fickle. The walk to the beach is part of the experience, but be prepared for mud! This is a great place to see seals.

spots.name: West Angle Bay
spots.description: A sheltered bay located near Pembroke, West Angle Bay offers a more mellow surfing experience. It's a good option for beginners and improvers, especially when other spots are too big. The beach is sandy and picturesque, with views across to Dale.
spots.bestSeason: All year round, but best in autumn and winter
spots.parking: Small car park right next to the beach.
spots.insiderTip: The cafe at the beach serves great food and drinks. This bay is more protected from prevailing winds so a good option if it's howling elsewhere. This is a very beautiful spot.

practicalInfo.weather: Pembrokeshire's weather is notoriously unpredictable. Be prepared for sunshine, rain, and wind, sometimes all in the same day. Keep an eye on the swell forecast and wind direction – offshore winds (blowing from the land to the sea) are ideal for surfing. Water temperatures can be cold, even in summer, so a good wetsuit is essential.
gearChecklist: Leash (to keep your board attached to you)
Surf wax (to provide grip on your board)
Rash vest (for extra warmth and sun protection)
Warm clothes for after your surf (hat, gloves, fleece)
First-aid kit (for minor cuts and scrapes)

gettingThere.publicTransport: Haverfordwest is the nearest train station to most surf spots. From there, you can take a bus or taxi. The Pembrokeshire Coast Path Bus (Sherpa) connects many of the coastal villages and beaches.
gettingThere.parkingTips: Parking can be limited at some beaches, especially during peak season. Arrive early or be prepared to walk. Some car parks are National Trust, so membership can save you money. Be respectful of local residents when parking.

practicalInfo.safety: Always check the surf forecast and tide times before you go. Be aware of rip currents, especially at Freshwater West. Never surf alone, and let someone know where you're going. If in doubt, don't go out! In an emergency, dial 999 and ask for the Coastguard. The RNLI provides lifeguard cover at some beaches during the summer months. Be aware of submerged rocks and other hazards.

faqs.question: What's the best time of year for surfing in Pembrokeshire?
faqs.answer: Autumn and winter (September to November) generally offer the most consistent swells. However, you can surf year-round, and the summer months can be great for beginners.

faqs.question: Is Freshwater West suitable for beginners?
faqs.answer: No, Freshwater West is generally not suitable for beginners due to its powerful waves and strong rips. Newgale, Whitesands Bay, and West Angle Bay are better options for beginners.

faqs.question: How much does it cost to rent a surfboard in Pembrokeshire?
faqs.answer: Surfboard hire typically costs around £15-£25 per day. Wetsuit hire is usually around £10-£15 per day. Check with local surf shops for specific prices.

faqs.question: Are there surf schools in Pembrokeshire?
faqs.answer: Yes, there are several surf schools in Pembrokeshire, including Outer Reef Surf School in Newgale and MUUK Adventures, who offer lessons at various locations. Prices typically range from £30-£60 for a 2-hour lesson.

faqs.question: What size wetsuit do I need for surfing in Pembrokeshire?
faqs.answer: A 5mm wetsuit is recommended, especially during the winter months. In summer, a 3/2mm wetsuit may be sufficient, but it's always better to be too warm than too cold.

faqs.question: Where can I find surf reports for Pembrokeshire?
faqs.answer: Magicseaweed and Windguru are popular websites for surf reports. Also, check local surf shops for the most up-to-date information.

faqs.question: Are there any surf competitions in Pembrokeshire?
faqs.answer: The Welsh National Surfing Championships are occasionally held at Freshwater West, but check the Welsh Surfing Federation website for specific dates and locations.

gearShops.name: Newsurf
gearShops.description: A well-stocked surf shop right on Newgale beach, offering surfboard and wetsuit hire, sales, and repairs. They also offer surf lessons.

gearShops.name: Ma Simes Surf Hut
gearShops.description: A cosy surf shop in St Davids, offering surfboard and wetsuit hire, sales, and accessories. They have a great selection of gear and a friendly atmosphere.

gearShops.name: West Wales Surf Shop
gearShops.description: A large surf shop in Haverfordwest, offering a wide range of surfboards, wetsuits, and accessories. They also have a good selection of clothing and footwear.

postActivitySpots.name: The Sloop Inn
postActivitySpots.description: A historic pub overlooking Porthgain harbour, The Sloop Inn is a popular spot for surfers and walkers alike. Known for its real ales, hearty food, and stunning views.

postActivitySpots.name: Bench Bar
postActivitySpots.description: Located right on Newgale beach, The Bench Bar is the perfect place to grab a post-surf beer and burger. They have a great outdoor seating area with views of the sea.

postActivitySpots.name: The Druidstone
postActivitySpots.description: A quirky and unique hotel and restaurant overlooking Broad Haven beach. Known for its delicious food, stunning views, and relaxed atmosphere.
postActivitySpots.knownFor: Fine dining, stunning views, quirky atmosphere

postActivitySpots.name: The Shed
postActivitySpots.description: A fish and chip restaurant with amazing fresh seafood and views of the harbour.

postActivitySpots.name: Bishops
postActivitySpots.address: 24 High St, St Davids, Haverfordwest SA62 6SD
postActivitySpots.description: A highly-rated cafe in St Davids, perfect for a post-surf coffee and cake. Friendly service and tasty treats.

postActivitySpots.name: Really Wild Emporium
postActivitySpots.description: Unique experience of wild food and fantastic coffee located right in St Davids

accommodation.name: Broad Haven YHA
accommodation.description: Budget-friendly hostel in a great location, close to Broad Haven beach. Perfect for surfers on a budget.

accommodation.name: Celtic Camping
accommodation.description: A campsite with stunning sea views, located near St Davids. A great base for exploring the Pembrokeshire coast and surfing at Whitesands Bay.

accommodation.name: The Warpool Court Hotel
accommodation.description: Hotel close to St Davids and Whitesands bay. Easy access to coastal walks and activities

accommodation.name: The Grove at Narberth
accommodation.description: A luxurious hotel experience and the perfect end to a day of adventuring at nearby Freshwater West

accommodation.name: B&B Dinas Country Club
accommodation.description: A B&B located at the end of the road to Dinas Head, ideal for surfing trips to north Pembrokeshire.

events.name: Welsh National Surfing Championships
events.description: Annual surfing competition showcasing the best surfers in Wales. Check the Welsh Surfing Federation website for details.
